channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: After Beirut Explosion, a Search for Survivors: Live Updates
item.description: Some 300,000 people are displaced from their homes by the explosion that killed more than 100 people. Rescue workers dug through rubble as fires continued to burn.
item.media:description: Damage in Beirut on Wednesday.

item.title: The Lebanon Explosions in Photos
item.description: Images from Beirut show the extent of the devastation from blasts that shook the Lebanese capital on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: An aerial view Wednesday of the blast site in Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: Beirut Explosion: 'I Was Bloodied and Dazed. Beirut Strangers Treated Me Like a Friend.'
item.description: In a land conditioned by calamity, people knew what to do, including helping wounded people they didn’t know.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: The injured being evacuated after a massive explosion in Beirut, Lebanon on Tuesday.

item.title: What Caused the Beirut Explosion? What We Know
item.description: More than 100 people were killed, and the second blast was felt as far away as Cyprus. An investigation and a search for survivors are underway.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Soldiers searching for survivors on Wednesday in Beirut, Lebanon.

item.title: India’s PM, Narendra Modi, Founds Temple on Ayodhya Mosque’s Ruins
item.description: In a ceremony in Ayodhya, a past flash point for sectarian violence, India’s prime minister offers his Hindu nationalist base a clear symbol of ascendancy.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Hari Kumar
item.media:description: Indians watching a live telecast from Ayodhya of Prime Minister Narendra Modi taking part in a Hindu religious ritual during a groundbreaking ceremony of the Ram Temple in New Delhi on Wednesday.

item.title: Kenya’s Unusual Solution to the School Problem: Cancel the Year and Start Over
item.description: Some students were taking classes online, while others couldn’t. So the government scrapped the school year for all. But the move may just make educational inequality worse.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Khadija Farah for The New York Times
item.media:description: Esther Adhiambo, center, attending a review class at a local community center in Nairobi. She must now repeat her senior year of high school, and says, “This pandemic has destroyed everything.”

item.title: Welcome Back to Germany. Now Take Your Free Coronavirus Test.
item.description: The country’s capacity to make testing efficient, affordable and available has distinguished it. Now, to head off a potential second wave, it’s testing anyone returning from a “hot zone” on entry.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Lining up at a test station at the Cologne airport last weekend. Testing became compulsory for some arrivals this week.

item.title: U.S. Health Secretary to Visit Taiwan, in a Move Likely to Anger Beijing
item.description: The trip by Alex M. Azar II, a rare high-level U.S. visit, is being billed as an opportunity to highlight Taiwan’s success in battling the coronavirus pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alex M. Azar II, the health and human services secretary, praised Taiwan as “a model of transparency and cooperation in global health during the Covid-19 pandemic.”

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Governors Seek to Reduce Testing Times in U.S.
item.description: Six states have entered a pact to reduce testing times. About one-third of Afghanistan’s population, or roughly 10 million people, have likely been infected by the coronavirus and recovered, its health ministry said.

item.title: Colombia Supreme Court Orders Ex-President Álvaro Uribe Detained
item.description: A decision to put Mr. Uribe under house arrest as a fraud and bribery investigation unfolds could be a turning point in a nation used to seeing powerful politicians avoid prosecution.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:description: Álvaro Uribe, center, was president of Colombia from 2002 to 2010, and is a mentor to the current president, Iván Duque, at right.

item.title: Trump’s Syria Sanctions ‘Cannot Solve the Problem,’ Critics Say
item.description: Without a broader diplomatic effort, the newest and toughest penalties will worsen a humanitarian crisis without forcing a leadership change, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Pranshu Verma and Vivian Yee
item.category: Office of Foreign Assets Control (United States Treasury)
item.media:description: Syrians fled the city of Ariha, in the Idlib Province, in March after government forces, backed by Russian air power, bombed parts of the region in an effort to obtain control. New sanctions by the United States could scare off companies interested in rebuilding Syria’s cities.

item.title: New Nominations to U.K. House of Lords Raise Old Concerns of Cronyism
item.description: Critics say Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s nominations for lifetime legislative posts continued a pattern of patronage that undermines the credibility of a long-troubled institution.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain released his first list of appointments to the House of Lords on Friday.

item.title: More U.S. Troops Will Leave Afghanistan Before the Election, Trump Says
item.description: The president’s assertion undercuts diplomats who have said withdrawals will depend on the Taliban’s commitment to its peace deal with the United States.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: In a recent interview, President Trump called U.S. involvement in the Middle East “the single biggest mistake in the history of our country.”

item.title: Peanut Butter and Ranch Dressing: What Americans Abroad Miss From Home
item.description: With virus cases in the United States rising and international travel curtailed, many Americans do not know when they will be able to reunite with home and the comforts they associate with it.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova

item.title: Who Gets Counted?
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: Sanam Yar and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:description: Times Square in Manhattan last year.

item.title: Beirut Blasts, Coronavirus, #MeToo: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: The port in Beirut on Tuesday.

item.title: Blasts Rock Beirut, Killing Dozens and Wounding Thousands
item.description: The cause remained unclear hours later. But officials in the Lebanese capital said 2,750 tons of highly explosive ammonium nitrate had been stored in a depot at the center of the explosion.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: An Army helicopter flying over the site of Tuesday’s blast in the port area of Beirut on Wednesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: A vaccine maker backed by the U.S. government is making progress.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga

item.title: Tanzania’s President Says Country Is Virus Free. Others Warn of Disaster
item.description: Tanzania hasn’t reported a single coronavirus case in three months, even as the African continent is expected this week to cross the threshold of one million reported cases.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: President John Magufuli of Tanzania in Mwanza in December. His country has not submitted information about coronavirus cases to the W.H.O. since April 29.

item.title: Beirut Blasts, Melbourne Lockdown, Island SOS: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Carole Landry
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: The port in Beirut on Tuesday.

item.title: Poor and Desperate, Pakistani Hindus Accept Islam to Get By
item.description: Drawn by jobs or land offered by Muslim groups, some Hindus, facing discrimination and a virus-ravaged economy, are essentially converting to survive.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Zia ur-Rehman
item.media:description: A protest last year in Karachi, Pakistan, against the forced conversions of Hindu girls to Islam. More voluntary forms of conversion, driven by the desire for a better life, are less often discussed.

item.title: Deadly Explosions Shatter Beirut, Lebanon
item.description: Dozens are dead and thousands hurt. The cause is unclear but the government said “highly explosive materials” had been stored at the blast scene in the Lebanese capital.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: The devastation near the port in Beirut on Tuesday.

item.title: 3 Men Marooned in the Pacific Are Rescued After Writing SOS in the Sand
item.description: Three days after their boat ran out of fuel and drifted off course in Micronesia, the men were found in good condition after a plane saw their giant plea for help spelled out on the sand.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Australian Defence Force, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An Australian Army helicopter landing on Sunday on the tiny island where the three stranded sailors were found.

item.title: Miles Apart on Coronavirus Relief
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick and Sanam Yar
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senator Chuck Schumer on Capitol Hill on Monday.

item.title: Melbourne is a Case Study in Navigating a Second Wave of Coronavirus
item.description: Melbourne, Australia’s second-largest city, is becoming a case study in handling a second wave of infections. There are lots of unanswered questions.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Police officers and soldiers in Melbourne, Australia, on Sunday, after tougher restrictions to curb the spread of the coronavirus were announced.

item.title: McConnell Signals Openness to Jobless Aid Extension
item.description: Tens of millions of Americans have lost crucial jobless benefits, and lawmakers still can’t seem to agree on a relief measure. Israel’s troubled school reopenings could be a lesson for the U.S.
item.media:description: Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, signaled he might be willing to accept the extension of the jobless-aid payments that many in his party oppose.

item.title: When Covid Subsided, Israel Reopened Its Schools. It Didn’t Go Well.
item.description: As countries consider back-to-school strategies for the fall, a coronavirus outbreak at a Jerusalem high school offers a cautionary tale.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Pam Belluck
item.media:description: Israeli health officials are divided as to whether the outbreak in schools spurred Israel’s second wave of infections.

item.title: TikTok, Spain’s Monarchy, Turkey: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai

item.title: Italy Leaders Hail Genoa’s New Bridge as Sign of Resilience
item.description: Less than two years after the collapse of the Morandi Bridge killed 43 people and embarrassed the nation, Italy inaugurated its replacement, and vowed to do better.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: The Frecce Tricolore Italian Air Force aerobatic squad flying over the new San Giorgio Bridge during its inauguration in Genoa, Italy, on Monday.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: The school year is underway in some parts of the United States — and we’re already seeing how fraught reopening classrooms can be.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Juan Carlos, Spain’s Former King, Quits Country Amid Multiple Investigations
item.description: The former king’s departure, which comes as he faces financial inquiries, may fuel Spain’s political and social debate over the future of the monarchy.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.media:description: The former king of Spain, Juan Carlos, center, announced on Monday he was leaving Spain amid inquiries into financial improprieties.

item.title: ‘I Am Scared’: Italian Sex Workers Face Poverty and Illness in the Pandemic
item.description: Prostitution is not illegal in Italy, nor is it regulated as an official occupation. But the coronavirus has forced many sex workers to accept certain risks in order to avoid poverty.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sex worker in Castel Volturno, southern Italy.

item.title: Turkish Aggression Is NATO’s ‘Elephant in the Room’
item.description: Despite being a NATO member, Turkey has bought Russian air defense. And a recent push into Libya and its energy ambitions nearly led to armed conflicts with France and Greece.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Turkey has become increasingly aggressive and nationalistic under President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, center left.

item.title: TikTok, Coronavirus, Spearfishing: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Carole Landry
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump reversed course after threatening to ban the app entirely from the United States.

item.title: Sotheby’s Reports $2.5 Billion in Sales
item.description: The auction house says that figure reflects a “resilient” market amid the coronavirus. But it represents a 25 percent decrease in auction sales, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Scott Reyburn
item.media:description: A Richter painting at a preview for “Rembrandt to Richter,” a Sotheby’s sale last week which was technically the first major live offering in London since the coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: Israel Says It Hit Bombers on Syrian Boundary
item.description: The military released grainy, edited footage of the ambush of what it said were four militants planting explosives in the area, amid heightened tensions along Israel’s northern frontiers.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: An Israeli military vehicle patrolling in the Golan Heights on Monday.

item.title: Poland’s Supreme Court Declares Presidential Election Valid
item.description: The decision comes after supporters of the opposition candidate filed protests questioning the narrow victory for the incumbent, Andrzej Duda.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.media:description: President Andrzej Duda of Poland was elected to a second term in the country’s closest presidential election since the end of communist rule in 1989.

item.title: What Has Changed Since George Floyd
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick and Sanam Yar
item.media:credit: Whitney Curtis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police during roll call at the Central Patrol Division for the third and fourth districts in St. Louis last year.

item.title: John Hume, Nobel Laureate for Work in Northern Ireland, Dies at 83
item.description: The politician’s campaign for peace was seen as a driving force behind an end to 25 years of sectarian conflict in the territory.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.category: Social Democratic and Labour Party (Northern Ireland)
item.media:description: John Hume, second from right, and the Northern Irish Protestant leader David Trimble, second from left, in Oslo in 1998.

item.title: Fauci Supports Birx’s Coronavirus Assessment After Trump Criticizes Her
item.description: Counting for the 2020 census will end on Sept. 30, a month earlier than previously announced, the Census Bureau said. Some U.S. schools have begun to reopen, with fraught results.
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci agreed with Dr. Deborah Birx’s statement that the United States has entered a “new phase” of the pandemic.

item.title: A Visit to 5 of Patagonia’s Most Remote Schoolhouses
item.description: Community life within the isolated villages of southern Chile is facilitated in part by an unlikely source: a network of rural schools.
item.dc:creator: Andria Hautamaki
item.category: Torres del Paine National Park (Patagonia, Chile)
item.media:description: Students play soccer in front of the rural school in Seno Obstrucción, a coastal village south of Puerto Natales.

item.title: ‘The Biggest Monster’ Is Spreading. And It’s Not the Coronavirus.
item.description: Tuberculosis kills 1.5 million people each year. Lockdowns and supply-chain disruptions threaten progress against the disease as well as H.I.V. and malaria.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Giorgio Franyuti said many patients with TB at a makeshift hospital in Mexico City were being misdiagnosed with Covid-19.

item.title: 29 Dead After ISIS Attack on Afghan Prison
item.description: The 20-hour gun battle left officials scrambling to recapture hundreds of prisoners, including many from the Islamic State and the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: Zabihullah Ghazi and Mujib Mashal
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Afghan security forces near the site of an attack on a jail compound in Jalalabad, on Monday. The casualties included civilians, inmates and security forces, officials said.

item.title: Abductions, Censorship and Layoffs: Pakistani Critics Are Under Siege
item.description: Recent abductions of a journalist and an activist have underscored Pakistan’s worsening rights conditions as the country’s security forces pressure the news media and human rights groups.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Kaneez Sughra, wife of the seized Pakistani journalist Matiullah Jan, shows a photograph of her husband. Mr. Jan was abducted from a street in Islamabad, Pakistan’s capital, in late July.

item.title: Vaccine Race, Donald Trump, SpaceX: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Sechenov Medical University Press Office, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A volunteer received a COVID-19 vaccine as part of clinical trials at Sechenov First Moscow State Medical University in June.

item.title: ‘Clean Up This Mess’: The Chinese Thinkers Behind Xi’s Hard Line
item.description: Chinese academics have been honing the Communist Party’s authoritarian response in Hong Kong, rejecting the liberal ideas of their youth.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tian Feilong, a Chinese intellectual in favor of Hong Kong’s new national security law, in Beijing. As a graduate student, he attended a traditionally more liberal university.

item.title: Israeli Court Rebukes Prime Minister’s Son Over Harassing Protest Leaders
item.description: Yair Netanyahu tweeted the addresses and phone numbers of three men who led protests against his father’s administration. All three said they later received death threats.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: An Israeli court ordered Yair Netanyahu, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s son, center, to stop harassing three people who led protests against his father’s administration.

item.title: Guyana Swears In New Leader, Resolving Struggle Over Oil Wealth
item.description: Mohamed Irfaan Ali will manage the flow of billions in new oil revenues, which are reshaping the small South American country and heightened a standoff after elections in March.
item.dc:creator: Nafeeza Yahya-Sakur and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mohamed Irfaan Ali was sworn in as Guyana’s president on Sunday after a five-month standoff. The country’s newly productive oil fields raised the election’s stakes.

item.title: Mexico Seizes Crime Boss El Marro, Under Pressure to Cut Violence
item.description: While the arrest of José Antonio Yépez delivers a major blow to a cartel, analysts say officials lack a cohesive strategy against debilitating crime.
item.dc:creator: Azam Ahmed
item.media:description: Crime by a cartel led by José Antonio Yépez, like the burning of this car to repel a police raid in March, has propelled violence in the Mexican state of Guanajuato to a crisis level.

item.title: Russia Sets Mass Vaccination for October After Shortened Trial
item.description: The announcement raised concerns that Russia would begin inoculations and declare victory in the race for a coronavirus vaccine without fully testing its product.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: An employee working at the Gamaleya Institute in Moscow in 2017. A Russian regulatory agency is expected to approve a vaccine developed by the Gamaleya Institute for use outside of trials.

item.title: Vaccine, TikTok, SpaceX: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Carole Landry
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vaccine assembly line at the Serum Institute in Pune, Maharshtra, India.

item.title: Militants Attack Afghan Prison as Brief Cease-Fire Expires
item.description: The Islamic State reportedly took responsibility for an assault at a time when releasing insurgents from prisons has become a major issue in the Afghan peace process.
item.dc:creator: Zabihullah Ghazi and Mujib Mashal
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A person wounded in an insurgent attack on a prison in Jalalabad, Afghanistan, was rushed for treatment at a hospital there on Sunday.

item.title: U.S. Small Business Bailout Money Flowed to Chinese-Owned Companies
item.description: Millions of dollars of Paycheck Protection Program loans went to China-backed businesses in critical sectors, a study found.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: Millions of dollars of American taxpayer money have flowed to China from the $660 billion Paycheck Protection Program that President Trump signed in April.

item.title: New Genoa Bridge Inauguration Is Bittersweet
item.description: Built in less than two years to replace the collapsed Morandi bridge, the new span is already a point of pride for Italy. But residents fear it will not be enough to revive their aging port city.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: The new Genoa San Giorgio bridge was built speedily, but its construction and other infrastructure repairs in the area have made life difficult for many Genoa residents.

item.title: Conservative U.K. Lawmaker Is Arrested Over Rape Accusations
item.description: The arrest of the lawmaker, who has not been publicly identified, poses problems for the government of Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: Complaints about bullying, abuse and sexual harassment in the British Parliament have circulated for years.

item.title: Birx Warns That U.S. Epidemic Is in a ‘New Phase’
item.description: Colleges are preparing to welcome students back to a complicated campus setting. India’s home minister tests positive.

item.title: Less Sex, More Viewers: Pandemic Boosts Mexico’s Flagging Telenovelas
item.description: Dismissed as too old-fashioned to compete with streaming services, the melodramas have seen viewership surge from Mexicans seeking the familiar in a distressing time.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mexico’s Televisa network has continued to shoot new telenovelas, as its traditional melodramas are known, through the pandemic.

item.title: U.A.E. Becomes First Arab Nation to Open a Nuclear Power Plant
item.description: The launch is raising concerns about the growing number of nuclear programs in the volatile Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee

item.title: Iran Says It Detained Leader of California-Based Exile Group
item.description: The detained man, Jamshid Sharmahd of the Kingdom Assembly of Iran, is accused of planning attacks on Iran, including a 2008 one that killed 14 and injured 200.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: Iran’s intelligence minister, Mahmoud Alavi, center, in Tehran last year. Mr. Alavi announced the arrest.
